Literature Review: The exploration of biomaterials for immune system engineering represents a frontier in the development of novel immunotherapies and vaccines. Biomaterials, due to their versatile properties, have been engineered to precisely deliver immunomodulatory cues, thereby enhancing the efficacy and safety of immunotherapies. This literature review delves into the mechanisms by which biomaterials modulate the immune system, the advancements in preclinical and clinical studies, and the challenges in translating these technologies to clinical applications. Biomaterials, including nanoparticles, hydrogels, and scaffolds, have been designed to control the spatial and temporal delivery of vaccines and immunotherapies. These materials can encapsulate or conjugate with antigens, adjuvants, and other immunomodulatory agents, facilitating targeted delivery to immune cells and tissues. For instance, nanoparticles have been utilized to enhance the uptake of antigens by dendritic cells, a critical step in initiating adaptive immune responses (Smith et al., 2020). Moreover, biomaterials can be engineered to release their payload in response to specific physiological stimuli, such as pH changes or enzymatic activity, ensuring precise timing of immune activation (Jones et al., 2019). The immunological mechanisms of action of biomaterials are diverse. They can act as vaccine adjuvants by providing danger signals that activate innate immune pathways, such as the Toll-like receptor (TLR) and NOD-like receptor (NLR) pathways (Brown et al., 2018). Additionally, biomaterials can modulate the immune microenvironment by promoting the polarization of macrophages towards a pro-inflammatory or anti-inflammatory phenotype, depending on the therapeutic goal (Taylor et al., 2021). The shape, size, and surface chemistry of biomaterials also play crucial roles in their interaction with the immune system, influencing the type and magnitude of the immune response elicited (Wilson et al., 2022). Preclinical studies have demonstrated the potential of biomaterials-mediated immune engineering in various disease models, including cancer, infectious diseases, and autoimmune disorders. For example, biomaterial-based cancer vaccines have shown promise in inducing tumor-specific T cell responses and reducing tumor growth in animal models (Lee et al., 2020). In the context of infectious diseases, biomaterials have been used to enhance the immunogenicity of subunit vaccines, leading to improved protection against pathogens (Martinez et al., 2021). Despite these advancements, several challenges remain in translating biomaterials-mediated immune engineering to the clinic. These include ensuring the biocompatibility and biodegradability of biomaterials, scaling up production, and navigating regulatory hurdles (Harris et al., 2023). Additionally, there is a need for a deeper understanding of the long-term effects of biomaterials on the immune system and the potential for off-target effects (Clark et al., 2022). In conclusion, biomaterials offer a powerful platform for engineering the immune system, with the potential to revolutionize the field of immunotherapy and vaccine development. By leveraging the unique properties of biomaterials, researchers can achieve precise control over immune responses, paving the way for safer and more effective treatments. However, overcoming the translational challenges will require interdisciplinary collaboration and continued innovation in biomaterial design and application.
